section.title: Use translation memories
section.para: When a project is initially created, it comes with its own empty project translation memory, , located in the folder. This memory is gradually filled as your translation progresses.
Existing translations are used to speed up the translation process.

listitem.para: If a given sentence has already been translated once, there is no need to retranslate it. See in the dialog.
If an old translation is similar to the contents of the segment you are translating, you can recycle it in your translation. See for details.
You can also make use of reference translation memories by putting them in the folder of your project.

section.title: Create your own TMs
section.para: When you use to create the target documents for a project, OmegaT also outputs three translation memories that reflect the current state of the translation for the files in the source folder (see ).

Each of the three files constitutes a bilingual export of the current content of your translation. Their content comes the global project memory () but is strictly limited to what you have translated so far.
You can also use the tool to create a TMX from two files in a format that OmegaT supports.

section.title: Reuse TMs
section.para:
To reuse translation memories from a previous project you have 2 options:
Open the old project and put the new source files in its folder.
After reloading the old project, all its translation memory will be applied to the new source files.
That’s the easiest way to work on the new version of an already translated document.
Put the reference memories that you took from the old project and put them in the folder of the new project. Depending on how reliable the memory is, you can prefer , , , or even if it comes from machine translation.
That’s the preferred method if you want to start your translation from scratch.

section.title: Reading TMs from other tools
section.para: OmegaT can read conformant TMX memories produced by other tools.

Some tools produce invalid TMX files under certain conditions. You will have to fix them if you want to use them as reference memories, otherwise OmegaT will report an error and fail to load them. Fixes are generally simple, and the error message provided by OmegaT will help you pinpoint the error. You can also ask the user group for advice if you have problems.

section.title: Managing your TMs
section.para:
You may want to store translation memories in separate folders, by client or by specialty so as to be able to reuse them quickly when need arises. In which case you will just need to use the appropriate folder as the
of your project.

section.title: Creating a TM specific to selected documents
section.para: In situations where you need to share a TMX that contain only the text from certain specific files and excludes other content, follow the procedure below:

listitem.para: Copy the documents for which you want to create a translation memory into the source folder of your project.
Use to find any untranslated segments (and eventually translate them),
Use to check for possible issues,
Use to create the TMX files that correspond to the current contents.

section.para: The TMX files located in the folder now contain only the original and translated text, in the selected language pair, of the files you copied into the source folder.

section.title: Share TMs
section.para: For large jobs involving a team of translators, it is easier for everyone involved in sharing common translation memories rather than pass local versions back and forth.

There are two ways to share translation memories:
The good enough way
See above.
If the folder where you write the TMX file to is on a shared disk, you can ask your partner to use that folder as the folder for the current translation.
Reciprocally, you can ask your partner to write project TMX files to a folder on a shared disk that you will use as your folder for the current translation.
OmegaT notices instantaneously when a TMX file has been modified so that anytime such a TMX is created on either side, with , the other side will not have anything to do to have that TMX be taken into account locally.
Such a sharing method works equally well for glossary sharing, where the ,with an appropriate name to avoid overwriting, is located in the that the partner will use only as reference, and reciprocally.
Such sharing works well when the lag between TMX updates is not important, for example, a translator sends data to a reviewer a few times a day.
The technical way
OmegaT uses collaborative version control systems to share data.
Such systems are free to use, install and manage and are widely used in the computer development world, making them extremely robust.
See for details.

section.title: Bridge two languages
section.para: OmegaT displays fuzzy matches in the pane. Such matches are by default limited to the source and target languages defined in , but you can also add matches in languages that are not the target language. See for details.
With OmegaT, you can also display a third language right under the source segment to use as an alternative language reference for the source text.

figure.title: Bridge two languages with a third

caption.para: English as the source language, French in translation, Japanese as "bridge" alternative language reference.

section.para:
To achieve this:
create a folder called tmx2source in the folder,
copy your "first-third" language translation memory there,
rename the memory LL_CC.tmx or LL-CC.tmx, where LL is the internal language code that you want to display as reference and CC is an arbitrary 2-letter code.
You can use any number of TMX files in as many different language pairs as "bridge" languages as you want.
Bridge two languages with many
English as the source language, French in translation, a French revision to check and Japanese as "bridge" third language reference.
The French revision TMX is also in to provide its matches when relevant.
